sourcesContent:
import React from 'react'; import { FontAwesomeIcon } from '@fortawesome/react-fontawesome'; import { faHeart, faThumbsUp, faAngleDown, faAngleUp, faAngleLeft, faAngleRight } from '@fortawesome/free-solid-svg-icons'; import { Col, Row, Button, Container, Dropdown, ButtonGroup } from 'react-bootstrap'; import Documentation from "../../components/Documentation"; export default () => { return (

Buttons TEST

Use custom button styles for actions in forms, dialogs, and more with support for multiple sizes, states, and more.

The <Button> component is an important part of the UI that you can use for user actions. If you want to change the appearance of a given button, you can update the modifier props of the variant attribute.

} scope={{ Button }} imports={`import { Button } from 'react-bootstrap';`} example={` `} /> The <Button> component comes with three main sizing options: sm, default, and lg. In order to change the size of the button you need to set the size using the size attribute.

} scope={{ Button }} imports={`import { Button } from 'react-bootstrap';`} example={` `} /> Instead of a fully colored background, you can also choose to style the <Button> component to only have an outline border by using the outline-primary, outline-secondary modifier classes inside the variant attribute.

} scope={{ Button }} imports={`import { Button } from 'react-bootstrap';`} example={` `} /> If you want to use the <Button> component, but without the appearance of a button, just use the bsPrefix="text" attribute to create link styled buttons.

} scope={{ Button }} imports={`import { Button } from 'react-bootstrap';`} example={` `} /> You may want to use icons inside the <Button> component, which can be done by simply adding a <FontAwesomeIcon> component inside the button element.

} scope={{ Button, FontAwesomeIcon, faHeart, faThumbsUp }} imports={`import { Button } from 'react-bootstrap'; import { FontAwesomeIcon } from "@fortawesome/react-fontawesome"; import { faHeart, faThumbsUp } from "@fortawesome/free-solid-svg-icons";`} example={` `} /> Block level buttons are great if you want the button to take up 100% of the width of the parent element. You need to add the w-100 class to the component.

} scope={{ Button }} imports={`import { Button } from 'react-bootstrap';`} example={``} /> You may want to disable the <Button> component for various reasons, so you need to add the disabled attribute in order to achieve that.

} scope={{ Button }} imports={`import { Button } from 'react-bootstrap';`} example={` `} />

Use the <Dropdown> component coupled with the <Button> component in order to create dropdown items when clicking on a button. The <Dropdown.Toggle> is the component that will trigger the dropdown menu, while the <Dropdown.Menu> is the actual menu where you can add the dropdown items.

The <Button> component is used either before or after the toggle component, but all of this is wrapped around with the main <Dropdown> component.

} scope={{ Button, Dropdown, ButtonGroup, FontAwesomeIcon, faAngleDown }} imports={`import { Button, Dropdown, ButtonGroup } from 'react-bootstrap'; import { FontAwesomeIcon } from "@fortawesome/react-fontawesome"; import { faAngleDown } from "@fortawesome/free-solid-svg-icons";`} example={` Action Another action Something else here Separated link Action Another action Something else here Separated link `} /> You may want to use one of the three main sizing options for the <Dropdown> component, so in order to do that you only need to use the size="md" or size="lg" attributes for the <Button> component inside the dropdown component.

} scope={{ Button, Dropdown, ButtonGroup, FontAwesomeIcon, faAngleDown }} imports={`import { Button, ButtonGroup, Dropdown } from 'react-bootstrap'; import { FontAwesomeIcon } from "@fortawesome/react-fontawesome"; import { faAngleDown } from "@fortawesome/free-solid-svg-icons";`} example={` Action Another action Something else here Separated link Action Another action Something else here Separated link Action Another action Something else here Separated link `} /> If you want to change the direction of the <Dropdown> component, you can do that by using the direction="*" attribute where you can use up, right, down, or left as attribute values.

} scope={{ Button, Dropdown, ButtonGroup, FontAwesomeIcon, faAngleDown, faAngleUp, faAngleLeft, faAngleRight }} imports={`import { Button, ButtonGroup, Dropdown } from 'react-bootstrap'; import { FontAwesomeIcon } from "@fortawesome/react-fontawesome"; import { faAngleDown, faAngleUp, faAngleLeft, faAngleRight } from "@fortawesome/free-solid-svg-icons";`} example={` Action Another action Something else here Separated link Action Another action Something else here Separated link Action Another action Something else here Separated link Action Another action Something else here Separated link `} />
); };
